title: Mormon church opposes bill banning gay conversion therapy in Utah
text:
A new bill banning conversion therapy has begun to take shape in Utah, but the prominent Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints announced their opposition on Tuesday – just months after the church said they wouldn’t fight a similar bill proposed earlier this year.

In their statement, the church said the ban is ‘ambiguous’, ‘overreaching’ and does not protect religious or parental rights.

‘The Church hopes that those who experience same-sex attraction and gender dysphoria find compassion and understanding from family members, Church leaders and members, and professional counselors. The Church denounces any abusive professional practice or treatment.’

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (pictured) have announced their opposition to a new bill in Utah the hopes to ban gay conversion therapy

‘We teach the right of individuals to self-determination and the right of parents to guide the development of their children. We also believe faith-based perspectives have an important and ethically appropriate role in professional counseling.’

The church asks that Utah lawmakers amend the bill to include their beliefs or provide clear guidance on the issue.

State officials drafted the most recent version of the bill at the behest of Republican Utah Governor Gary Herbert, a member of the church.

Herbert asked for a set of formal rule’s to be made regarding the topic in a similar bill drafted earlier this year.

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints released a statement on Tuesday (pictured) outlining their hesitation about the bill and saying it impedes on their religious rights

The Utah Department of Commerce and the Utah Division of Occupational and Professional Licensing were tasked with drafting the original bill.

In preparation, LGBTQ+ advocates and organizations spoke out in support with hopes that Utah, known for its overwhelming conservatism, would become the 18th state to have laws banning conversation therapy.

A coalition of mental health representatives and non-profit leaders banded together with two GOP lawmakers to finish the task.

The church said they would not object the bill.

However, the bill died after consistent attacks from right-wing groups that claimed the bill would muzzle therapists.

This time around, the church is taking a much more vocal stance.

Utah Republican Governor Gary Herbert (pictured) asked committees to create formal rules regarding to gay conversion therapy and wants to use 'the best science available' as the basis

‘We therefore oppose the proposed rule in its current form and respectfully request that it be appropriately amended to address the concerns raised in Family Services’ comments, or that Utah’s lawmakers provide statutory guidance on this important issue,’ the statement said.

How their stance will affect the decision remains to be seen, but it would be unsurprising if it drew support from followers and state residents.

The church, or the Mormon church, is the faith of choice for almost two-thirds of the state’s occupants and almost every state lawmaker.

LGBTQ+ advocate and director for Equality Utah posted a photo on his Twitter (pictured) showcasing the the suicide risks associated with transgender children who undergo conversion therapy

The Mormon church is the fourth largest denomination in the country and has approximately 16 million members worldwide.

According to the church’s website, their general stance on LGBTQ+ and same sex relationships are stringent.

Those who act on their feelings for same-sex marriage face three outcomes: a probation period, becoming ‘disfellowshipped’ or excommunication.

The Utah Division of Occupational and Professional Licensing said the new rule could begin as early as next week.

LGBTQ advocate and Equality Utah director, Troy Williams, called the church’s recent statement ‘profoundly disappointing.’

He told Fox 13: ‘The proposed rule would do nothing more than protect LGBTQ children from conversion therapy — a life-threatening practice that has been condemned by all of the state’s and the nation’s medical and mental health authorities.’

‘Studies have found that more than 60% of children subjected to conversion therapy attempt suicide. Suicide is the leading cause of death among Utah’s children, and LGBTQ youth are especially vulnerable.’

‘It’s long past time to protect our state’s youth by prohibiting this dangerous practice.’

Despite that, Williams and other advocates are supporting Herbert’s request to base the upcoming bill on scientific facts and studies.

Herbert asked the board to use the ‘the best available science.’

Williams (pictured) called The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints recent statement 'profoundly disappointing'

Williams was a member of Gov. Herbert’s suicide prevention task force, but quit after he disagreed with Herbert's handling of the first bill.

In hearing last month, members of the LBTGQ+ community mirrored Williams’ statements about the risk of children’s mental health and gay conversion therapy.

Nathan Dalley, a man who attempted suicide while undergoing conversion therapy, said the process is harmful to children.

‘The adults in this room have failed youth, and they failed me. These are professionals that are ignoring the consensus that conversion therapy doesn’t work. It’s harmful. It’s been harmful to me,’ Dalley said, according to KSL.

Jason Lindow, a transgender man who identified as lesbian before transitioning, shared similar thoughts.

LGBTQ+ advocates and supporters have reminded lawmakers of how a minor's mental health can be harmed when they undergo gay conversion therapy

‘I felt like they were trying to break me apart as a person and use the shattered pieces to try and put me back together again.’

‘I felt dead inside.’

The American Psychiatric Association has and continues to vehemently oppose gay conversion therapy.

On their website, they say: ‘In the wake of recent popular entertainment portrayals of conversion therapy, the American Psychiatric Association (APA) today reiterates its long-standing opposition to the practice.’

‘APA made clear with its 1998 position statement that “APA opposes any psychiatric treatment, such as “reparative” or “conversion” therapy, that is based on the assumption that homosexuality per se is a mental disorder or is based on the a prior assumption that the patient should change his or her homosexual orientation.’

The association says they do not believe same-sex orientation should or needs to be remedied.
description: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has come out in opposition to a proposed bill in Utah that would ban conversation therapy, saying it would infringe on their religious rights
